questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of lower abdominal pain for the past 5 days. The pain is constant and she describes it as 7 out of 10 in intensity. Over the past 7 months, she has had multiple similar episodes of abdominal pain, each lasting for 4–5 days. Menarche has not yet occurred. Examination shows suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Pubic hair and breast development are Tanner stage 4. Examination of the external genitalia shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows a bulging, bluish membrane under the labia. Rectal examination shows an anterior tender mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparoscopy is both a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used for pathology in the abdomen and pelvis that cannot be readily diagnosed using imaging modalities. This patient's history and physical examination make imperforate hymen very likely. In unclear cases, further workup would include sonography or possibly MRI. Exploratory laparoscopy is not the next best step, nor will it likely be needed in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) suppress menstruation and can thus be used for treating dysmenorrhea associated with endometriosis or primary dysmenorrhea. While this therapy can be used as a temporary solution to help relieve symptoms, it does not address the vaginal obstruction, nor should definitive treatment be delayed in an adolescent girl who has not had menarche.

C) INCORRECT:

Vaginal dilation is a treatment for vulvovaginal atrophy and vaginal atresia. It is not useful for treating an imperforate hymen because it does not remove the obstructing hymenal tissue that causes dysmenorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are used for symptomatic management of primary dysmenorrhea. While this class of medication may help decrease the pain associated with an imperforate hymen, it would not treat the vaginal obstruction in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Hymenotomy is the treatment of choice in patients with imperforate hymen. During the procedure, an incision is performed at the base of the hymen, and the obstructing tissue is excised (hymenectomy). Menstrual blood is then drained from the upper vaginal canal. Patients' menses usually normalize and menstrual pain decreases after this procedure.

F) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist therapy is often used to promote fertility by regulating the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovary axis and, less commonly, to treat dysmenorrhea associated with endometriosis. It is not used in the treatment of an imperforate hymen, as it does not address the issue of vaginal obstruction.
questions.hint: In a 15-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea and cyclical abdominal pain, the presence of a tender mass on palpation of the anterior rectal wall and a bulging, bluish vaginal membrane is consistent with hematocolpos due to an imperforate hymen.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Examination shows normal breast development. Pubic hair is coarse and extends to the inner surface of the thighs. Pelvic examination shows a blind vaginal pouch. Ultrasonography shows ovaries, but no uterus. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of 17-alpha hydroxylase results in a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia that may manifest with primary amenorrhea in females as a result of impaired estrogen synthesis. However, a uterus would be present on ultrasonography and external genitalia would be normal. Pubic hair would be scarce due to hypoandrogenism, and breast development would be delayed. Patients would also have other clinical features such as hypertension and hyperpigmentation.

B) CORRECT:

Mullerian duct agenesis is a rare congenital defect in which the Mullerian ducts fail to fuse. As a result, the uterus, cervix, and upper third of the vagina are atretic. Patients are asymptomatic until puberty when they present with primary amenorrhea. The secondary sexual characteristics are usually normal since the gonads are functional and the patient has a normal female karyotype. The treatment is primarily surgical, involving uterine transplantation and vaginoplasty.
Image Description:

(1) Uniform (sex-independent) embryonic genital (and urinary) structures (before week 8)
(2) Degeneration of the Wolffian ducts and differentiation of the Mullerian ducts
(3) Fully developed female urogenital organs

C) INCORRECT:

5-alpha-reductase deficiency may present with primary amenorrhea, a blind vaginal loop, and an absent uterus on ultrasonography. However, patients would also have features of virilization (e.g., clitoromegaly, hirsutism, and deepening of the voice) at the time of puberty, and the ultrasound would reveal undescended testes.
Image Description:

Individuals with 5-alpha reductase deficiency are karyotypically male but often grow up with a female gender identity. At birth, external male genitalia and the prostate are underdeveloped because these organs are dependent on dihydrotestosterone for in-utero development. During puberty, testosterone levels increase, resulting in the development of secondary male sexual characteristics, and some individuals undergo a change in gender identity.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome present with primary amenorrhea, a blind vaginal pouch, an absent uterus on ultrasonography, and normal breast development. However, patients would not have pubic hair, since the growth of pubic hair is dependent on androgens. Ultrasonography would reveal undescended testicles.

E) INCORRECT:

Sex chromosomal monosomy results in Turner syndrome, which may manifest with primary amenorrhea. However, other features such as short stature, webbing of the neck, lymphedema, and/or shield chest would also be present. The secondary sexual characteristics are usually poorly developed. In most cases, the vagina, cervix, and uterus are present, but the ovaries are typically hypoplastic.

F) INCORRECT:

Pure gonadal dysgenesis typically manifests with primary amenorrhea. However, the external female genitalia would be normal, and patients would not develop secondary sexual characteristics (e.g., pubic hair, breast development). The uterus would be present on ultrasonography but the ovaries would be hypoplastic or replaced by fibrous streaks.

G) INCORRECT:

Failure of recanalization of the Mullerian duct would result in a transverse vaginal septum, which would manifest with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and a blind vaginal pouch. However, patients would complain of periodic abdominal pain due to hematometra and would show a distended uterine cavity with variable internal echogenicity on ultrasound.
questions.hint: Urological malformations (e.g., renal agenesis, horseshoe kidney, pelvic kidney) are commonly associated with this condition.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, aborta 1, comes to the physician for evaluation of irregular menstrual periods. Menarche was at the age of 12 years. Her menses have always occurred at variable intervals, and she has spotting between her periods. Her last menstrual period was 7 months ago. Her one previous pregnancy resulted in a spontaneous, incomplete abortion at 12 weeks'  gestation that was managed with dilation and curettage. Medical history otherwise is unremarkable and she takes no routine medications. She drinks 3 alcoholic drinks on weekends and does not smoke. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Prolactin, FSH, and TSH levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive therapy can be used to replace estrogen and provide contraception in patients with premature ovarian failure (POF), which manifests with secondary amenorrhea. However, this patient's normal levels of FSH exclude POF.

Oral contraceptive therapy can also be used in the management of menstrual abnormalities in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which can manifest with secondary amenorrhea. However, treatment can only be initiated once PCOS is diagnosed based on the presence of at least two of the Rotterdam criteria. This patient does not have symptoms of hyperandrogenism (e.g., acne, hirsutism) and she would require further evaluation of the ovaries on pelvic ultrasound for the diagnosis of PCOS.

B) CORRECT:

Progesterone withdrawal test is recommended for patients with secondary amenorrhea who are not pregnant and have normal levels of hypothalamic-pituitary hormones (i.e., prolactin, FSH, and TSH). Progesterone is administered for 10 days, after which the patient is observed for withdrawal bleeding. Progesterone withdrawal bleeding confirms that the patient has normal estrogen levels (which leads to the proliferation of the endometrium) and that anovulation is the cause of secondary amenorrhea (anovulation leads to absent corpus luteum, which would otherwise produce progesterone). The absence of withdrawal bleeding suggests hypoestrogenism (due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism or primary ovarian failure) or uterine obstruction. In such cases, a combined estrogen and progesterone challenge should be performed. Following this combined test, withdrawal bleeding suggests hypoestrogenism, and the absence of bleeding suggests the presence of uterine outflow obstruction (e.g., due to Asherman syndrome). In the latter, a hysteroscopy or hysterosalpingogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Image Description:

The menstrual cycle consists of two phases: the follicular and the luteal phase. The onset of menses marks the beginning of the follicular phase, which usually lasts 12–14 days but may be variable. The luteal phase begins on the day of ovulation and lasts 14 days.

During the follicular phase, FSH and LH stimulate the development of several follicles, one of which develops as the dominant follicle into the Graafian follicle. An LH surge initiates ovulation. As the oocyte reaches the fallopian tube, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. If no pregnancy occurs, the corpus luteum regresses and the progesterone level drops. This drop induces vasospasms in the uterine spiral arteries, ischemia, and sloughing off of the functional endometrial layer, which leads to menstrual bleeding (menstrual phase). During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is built up again in preparation for oocyte implantation during the secretory phase.

1: stages of follicle development; 2: hormone levels; 3: phases of the endometrial cycle; 4: development of the endometrium during the cycle

C) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy can be performed in women who are at risk for intrauterine adhesions (e.g., due to history of uterine instrumentation), which can manifest with secondary amenorrhea and normal hypothalamic-pituitary hormones. Intrauterine adhesions can disrupt normal endometrial growth and result in uterine outflow obstruction, with consequent amenorrhea. However, a different diagnostic test should be performed before considering hysteroscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin therapy is used to treat patients with impaired fertility due to anovulation (e.g., as a result of polycystic ovarian syndrome or premature ovarian failure). Although anovulation can not yet be excluded as the cause of this patient's amenorrhea, she has not reported a history of infertility or a wish to conceive in the future. Moreover, before initiating any treatment, additional workup is required to confirm the cause of this patient's amenorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

A dexamethasone suppression test is used to diagnose Cushing syndrome, which can manifest with amenorrhea, obesity, and normal hypothalamic-pituitary hormones. However, the absence of other clinical features such as hypertension, abdominal striae, abnormal cutaneous fat deposit, hirsutism, and/or emotional lability makes this diagnosis unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain is indicated for patients with secondary amenorrhea and concurrent hyperprolactinemia to assess for the presence of a prolactinoma. This patient, however, has normal prolactin levels. A different step is more appropriate at this time.
questions.hint: The absence of menses for more than 6 months in a woman with previously irregular menstrual cycles is consistent with secondary amenorrhea. This patient's normal prolactin, TSH, and FSH concentrations and negative pregnancy test rule out prolactinoma, hypothyroidism, ovarian insufficiency, and pregnancy as underlying causes of amenorrhea.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician because she has been unable to conceive for the past year. During this time, she has not had a menstrual period. She also reports episodic pelvic pain that occurs every 4 weeks and lasts for several days. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals. She is sexually active with her husband and does not use contraceptives. Her child was born at term after vaginal delivery 14 months ago. The postpartum course was complicated by hemorrhage from retained placental products, for which the patient underwent uterine curettage. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Speculum examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. The uterus is normal in size, and no adnexal masses are palpated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Midcycle serum studies show:


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
3.9 μU/mL


Follicle-stimulating hormone
54 mIU/mL


Luteinizing hormone
110 mIU/mL


Prolactin
15 ng/mL


β-hCG
negative


Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Measurement of midluteal serum progesterone concentration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measurement of midluteal serum progesterone levels is used to assess ovulatory function in patients with a history of infertility and secondary amenorrhea. Anovulation can be caused by primary hypogonadism (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome, primary ovarian insufficiency) or secondary hypogonadism (e.g., hyperprolactinemia due to prolactinoma). In this patient with normal serum hormone studies, amenorrhea and infertility are unlikely to be caused by anovulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic laparoscopy is a confirmatory test for endometriosis, which can manifest with cyclic pelvic pain and infertility. However, this patient has amenorrhea, which is not a feature of endometriosis. In addition, physical examination in endometriosis typically shows rectovaginal tenderness, adnexal masses, and lateral displacement of the cervix, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain is the preferred imaging modality to confirm Sheehan syndrome (SS). SS is caused by ischemia and necrosis of the pituitary gland due to severe postpartum hemorrhage. Patients with SS typically have LH and FSH deficiency. Although SS also manifests with secondary amenorrhea and infertility, this patient has normal levels of LH and FSH, making SS unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid antibody testing is used to confirm suspected autoimmune thyroiditis, such as Hashimoto disease, which is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in the US. Overt hypothyroidism may result in amenorrhea and subsequent infertility. However, a compensatory increase in thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels is expected, whereas this patient's TSH is within the reference range.

E) CORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is a confirmatory test for intrauterine adhesions, also known as Asherman syndrome (AS). AS most commonly occurs following intrauterine instrumentation (e.g., dilation and curettage) and may manifest with infertility, secondary amenorrhea, and cyclic pelvic pain (due to blood accumulation in the uterus). Serum concentrations of FSH, LH, and prolactin are typically within the reference ranges. AS is usually asymptomatic; the standard treatment for symptomatic AS is hysteroscopic resection of the adhesions.

The workup of secondary amenorrhea includes a progestin and/or an estrogen/progestin withdrawal test, which induces withdrawal bleeding in patients with anovulatory cycles (e.g., due to polycystic ovary syndrome, primary ovarian insufficiency). Because of the presence of intrauterine adhesions and blocked outflow tract, these tests do not cause bleeding in patients with AS.
questions.hint: This patient's infertility and secondary amenorrhea most likely developed as a complication of uterine curettage.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain. Over the past 9 months, she has had multiple similar episodes of abdominal pain, each lasting for 4–5 days. Menarche has not yet occurred. Examination shows suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Pubic hair and breast development are Tanner stage 4. Pelvic examination shows bulging, bluish tissue 1 cm inside the vaginal introitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Labial adhesions manifest with a thin, vertical midline fold in the perineum due to adhesions between the labia minora. This condition does not cause a mass at the vaginal introitus and is typically asymptomatic. Additionally, this condition usually affects infants and young children (peak incidence of 2 years of age) and spontaneously resolves around the time of puberty, when increased circulating levels of estrogen thicken the labia. Patients with labial adhesions typically do not have primary amenorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) manifests with primary amenorrhea in patients with normal breast development and female external genitalia. However, in contrast to this patient, individuals with AIS have very sparse or absent pubic hair. Pelvic examination shows a blind-ending vaginal pouch rather than a mass at the vaginal introitus. Cryptorchid testes may be palpable as bilateral masses in the abdominal or inguinal region. AIS does not cause cyclical pelvic pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis causes cyclical pelvic pain, which is seen in this patient, but does not manifest with primary amenorrhea or a bulging, bluish mass within the vaginal introitus. Additionally, this condition typically manifests in women who are 25–35 years of age and is unlikely to develop in an adolescent patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Ectopic pregnancy can cause pelvic pain, but the pain is usually acute, nonrecurring, and develops in a postmenarchal patient after 4–6 weeks of amenorrhea (secondary amenorrhea). This patient, who has primary amenorrhea, has had recurring symptoms for 9 months. Moreover, while ectopic pregnancy can lead to an enlarged uterus or an adnexal mass, it would not manifest as a mass within the vaginal introitus.

E) CORRECT:

Imperforate hymen manifests with primary amenorrhea, cyclical pelvic pain, and otherwise normal secondary sexual characteristics. As is the case here, patients with an imperforate hymen are asymptomatic until menarche, when the obstructed outflow of menstrual blood distends the vaginal tract and uterus and results in a characteristic bulging, bluish mass at the vaginal introitus (hematocolpos). Treatment of imperforate hymen includes hymenectomy and consequent evacuation of the retained blood.

F) INCORRECT:

Müllerian agenesis (MA) manifests as primary amenorrhea in patients with normal secondary sexual characteristics. This condition causes vaginal agenesis; pelvic examination typically shows normal external genitalia and a vaginal dimple (small vaginal pouch) rather than a mass at the vaginal introitus. In almost all cases, individuals with MA also have uterine agenesis or underdevelopment and thus do not menstruate. Rarely, these individuals have a rudimentary uterus and can develop cyclic pelvic pain due to menstruation. However, because the menstrual blood cannot pass into the lower vagina, a mass would not be present at the vaginal introitus.
questions.hint: Recurrent lower abdominal pain in a 15-year-old female with age-appropriate secondary sexual characteristics suggests that menstruation is in fact occurring but is hidden (cryptomenorrhea)!

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period. Examination shows normal breast development. There is coarse pubic and axillary hair. Pelvic examination shows a blind vaginal pouch. Ultrasonography shows normal ovaries and an atretic uterus. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Failure of the mullerian duct to recanalize

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Failure of recanalization of the Müllerian ducts (paramesonephric ducts) would result in a transverse vaginal septum, which would present with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and a blind vaginal pouch. However, patients would complain of periodic abdominal pain due to hematometra and ultrasound would show a distended uterine cavity with variable internal echogenicity.

B) INCORRECT:

5-alpha-reductase deficiency can present with primary amenorrhea, a blind vaginal loop, and an absent uterus on ultrasound. However, patients would also have features of virilization (e.g., clitoromegaly, hirsutism, and deepening of the voice) at the time of puberty, and the ultrasound would reveal undescended testes.
Image Description:

Individuals with 5-alpha reductase deficiency are karyotypically male but often grow up with a female gender identity. At birth, external male genitalia and the prostate are underdeveloped because these organs are dependent on dihydrotestosterone for in-utero development. During puberty, testosterone levels increase, resulting in the development of secondary male sexual characteristics, and some individuals undergo a change in gender identity.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome present with primary amenorrhea, a blind vaginal pouch, an absent uterus on ultrasound, and normal breast development. However, patients would not have pubic hair, since the growth of pubic hair is dependent on androgens. Ultrasound would reveal undescended testes.

D) INCORRECT:

Monosomy of sex chromosomes results in Turner syndrome, which can present with primary amenorrhea. However, features such as short stature, webbing of the neck, lymphedema of the hands and feet, and/or widely spaced nipples would also be present. Secondary sexual characteristics are usually poorly developed. The vagina, cervix, and uterus are usually present, but the ovaries are fibrotic and hypoplastic (streak gonads).

E) CORRECT:

Agenesis of the paramesonephric duct, or Müllerian agenesis, results in an atretic uterus, cervix, and upper third of the vagina. Patients are asymptomatic until puberty, when they present with primary amenorrhea. Development of secondary sexual characteristics occurs normally, since the gonads are functional and the patient has a normal female karyotype.

The treatment is primarily surgical, involving uterine transplantation and vaginoplasty. Urological malformations such as renal agenesis and pelvic kidney are commonly associated with agenesis of the paramesonephric duct.
Image Description:

(1) Uniform (sex-independent) embryonic genital (and urinary) structures (before week 8)
(2) Degeneration of the Wolffian ducts and differentiation of the Mullerian ducts
(3) Fully developed female urogenital organs

F) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of 17-alpha-hydroxylase results in a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia that may present with primary amenorrhea in females as a result of impaired estrogen synthesis. However, the uterus would appear normal on ultrasound and external genitalia would also be normal. Pubic hair would be scarce due to hypoandrogenism, and breast development would be delayed. Patients would also have other clinical features, such as hypertension and hyperpigmentation.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome.

questions.text: An 18-month-old girl is brought to the office by her father for a well-child examination. She has had two urinary tract infections in the past 6 months. She appears well. Growth and development are appropriate for age. She is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows a thin perineal fold between the anus and urethral meatus and a normal clitoris. The vaginal opening and posterior labia minora cannot be identified. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroid injection is indicated for vulvar lichen sclerosus, which can manifest with labial fusion in advanced disease and result in recurrent urinary tract infections. This condition most commonly affects postmenopausal women (and less commonly, prepubertal girls around 7–8 years of age); it is rare in very young children. In addition, vulvar lichen sclerosus characteristically manifests with white papules that coalesce into plaques, which this patient does not have. Corticosteroid injection is not an appropriate treatment for partial labial fusion.
Image Description:

Photographs of two pediatric vulvas

Porcelain-white, polygonal, well-demarcated plaques in a figure-eight appearance involve the vulvar and perianal area. In the left picture, the atrophic patches are surrounded by an inflammatory erythematous halo.

These findings are typical of lichen sclerosus.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision is indicated for imperforate or incomplete fenestrated hymen, which can result in dysuria, urinary retention, and recurrent urinary tract infections if bulging in the vagina obstructs urination. Individuals with this condition are usually asymptomatic until the onset of menarche (at which point hematocolpos can develop), so this diagnosis is unlikely in an 18-month-old patient. Surgical excision is not an appropriate treatment for partial labial fusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Vaginoplasty is indicated for children with vaginal agenesis or vaginal atresia (Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome). Individuals with this condition typically have normal-appearing external genitalia, and are only symptomatic later in life (e.g., amenorrhea and cyclic pelvic pain in adolescence). Vaginoplasty is not an appropriate treatment for partial labial fusion.

D) CORRECT:

Labial fusion can manifest with dysuria, urinary frequency, and recurrent urinary tract infections. Application of estrogen cream is the first-line therapy for symptomatic labial fusion. The etiology of this condition is likely multifactorial and may involve thinning of the vulvar epithelial lining from low levels of estrogen (due to postpartum loss of in utero exposure to maternal estrogen) and chronic inflammation (e.g., from recurrent urinary tract infections). Peak incidence is at 1–2 years of age. Labial fusion can be partial or complete; this patient has a partial labial fusion, in which the urethral meatus and clitoris can be identified.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and observation are appropriate for asymptomatic labial fusion, which usually involves only a small part of the labia (partial labial fusion), does not affect urination (e.g., result in postvoid dribbling), and resolves spontaneously. This patient's labial fusion involves a large area that has obscured the vaginal opening and posterior labia minora and has resulted in recurrent urinary tract infections, so this would not be the most appropriate approach.
questions.hint: The physical examination finding of a vertical midline fold in the perineum indicates that the patient has a labial fusion, which obstructs the vaginal opening.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman reports a 2-year history of monthly lower abdominal pain and severe cramping. She has never been sexually active and has never had a period. She started developing pubic hair and breasts at age 11. She is otherwise well and participates in several sports. Her mother has a single kidney.
On examination, the patient has a BMI of 24.8. She has normal secondary sexual characteristics.
What finding on pelvic examination is most likely to explain this patient’s amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Primary amenorrhea refers to the absence of menstruation by age 16 with normal secondary sexual characteristics or by age 14 without secondary sexual characteristics. Primary amenorrhea can be caused by a lower genital tract anomaly and outflow obstruction, hypothalamo-pituitary problems, chromosomal anomalies, or genetic defects. All patients with primary amenorrhea should have a thorough history and physical examination, including a pelvic examination.

Structural abnormalities of the lower genital tract, such as an imperforate hymen or a vaginal septum, can be diagnosed on clinical examination or with pelvic imaging. Patients with an imperforate hymen often present with hematocolpos (a vagina distended with blood).

Key learning point: The most likely cause of primary amenorrhea in a young woman with monthly abdominal cramping pain and normal secondary sexual characteristics is an imperforate hymen.

B) INCORRECT:

Müllerian anomalies, such as a bicornuate uterus, do not cause amenorrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital absence of the uterus is not typically associated with monthly abdominal cramping.

D) INCORRECT:

Vaginal aplasia is not typically associated with monthly abdominal cramping.

E) INCORRECT:

Müllerian anomalies, such as a unicornuate uterus, do not cause amenorrhea.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl reports a 2-year history of monthly lower abdominal pain and severe cramping. She has never been sexually active and has never had a period. She started developing pubic hair and breasts at age 11. She is otherwise well and participates in several sports. Her mother has a single kidney.
On examination, the patient has a BMI of 24.8. She has normal secondary sexual characteristics.
What finding on pelvic examination is most likely to explain this patient’s amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Primary amenorrhea refers to the absence of menstruation by age 15 with normal secondary sexual characteristics, by age 14 without secondary sexual characteristics, or by 3 years post-thelarche. Primary amenorrhea can be caused by a lower genital tract anomaly and outflow obstruction, hypothalamo-pituitary problems, chromosomal anomalies, or genetic defects. All patients with primary amenorrhea should have a thorough history and physical examination, including a pelvic examination.

Structural abnormalities of the lower genital tract, such as an imperforate hymen or a vaginal septum, can be diagnosed on clinical examination or with pelvic imaging. Patients with an imperforate hymen often present with hematocolpos (a vagina distended with blood).

Key learning point: The most likely cause of primary amenorrhea in an adolescent with monthly abdominal cramping pain and normal secondary sexual characteristics is an imperforate hymen.

B) INCORRECT:

Congenital absence of the uterus and vaginal aplasia are not typically associated with monthly abdominal cramping.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital absence of the uterus and vaginal aplasia are not typically associated with monthly abdominal cramping.

D) INCORRECT:

Müllerian anomalies, such as a bicornuate uterus or a unicornuate uterus, do not cause amenorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

Müllerian anomalies, such as a bicornuate uterus or a unicornuate uterus, do not cause amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain. Over the past 9 months, she has had multiple similar episodes of abdominal pain, each lasting for 4–5 days. Menarche has not yet occurred. Examination shows suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Pubic hair and breast development are Tanner stage 4. Pelvic examination shows bulging, bluish tissue 1 cm inside the vaginal introitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Labial adhesions manifest with a thin, vertical midline fold in the perineum due to adhesions between the labia minora. This condition does not cause a mass at the vaginal introitus and is typically asymptomatic. Additionally, this condition usually affects infants and young children (peak incidence of 2 years of age) and spontaneously resolves around the time of puberty, when increased circulating levels of estrogen thicken the labia. Patients with labial adhesions typically do not have primary amenorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) manifests with primary amenorrhea in patients with normal breast development and female external genitalia. However, in contrast to this patient, individuals with AIS have very sparse or absent pubic hair. Pelvic examination shows a blind-ending vaginal pouch rather than a mass at the vaginal introitus. Cryptorchid testes may be palpable as bilateral masses in the abdominal or inguinal region. AIS does not cause cyclical pelvic pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis causes cyclical pelvic pain, which is seen in this patient, but does not manifest with primary amenorrhea or a bulging, bluish mass within the vaginal introitus. Additionally, this condition typically manifests in women who are 25–35 years of age and is unlikely to develop in an adolescent patient.

D) CORRECT:

Imperforate hymen manifests with primary amenorrhea, cyclical pelvic pain, and otherwise normal secondary sexual characteristics. As is the case here, patients with an imperforate hymen are asymptomatic until menarche, when the obstructed outflow of menstrual blood distends the vaginal tract and uterus and results in a characteristic bulging, bluish mass at the vaginal introitus (hematocolpos). Treatment of imperforate hymen includes hymenectomy and consequent evacuation of the retained blood.

E) INCORRECT:

Müllerian agenesis (MA) manifests as primary amenorrhea in patients with normal secondary sexual characteristics. This condition causes vaginal agenesis; pelvic examination typically shows normal external genitalia and a vaginal dimple (small vaginal pouch) rather than a mass at the vaginal introitus. In almost all cases, individuals with MA also have uterine agenesis or underdevelopment and thus do not menstruate. Rarely, these individuals have a rudimentary uterus and can develop cyclic pelvic pain due to menstruation. However, because the menstrual blood cannot pass into the lower vagina, a mass would not be present at the vaginal introitus.
questions.hint: Recurrent lower abdominal pain in a 15-year-old female with age-appropriate secondary sexual characteristics suggests that menstruation is in fact occurring but is hidden (cryptomenorrhea).

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the office because she has been unable to conceive for the past year. During this time, she has not had a menstrual period. She also reports episodic pelvic pain that occurs every 4 weeks and lasts for several days. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals. The postpartum course of her first pregnancy was complicated by hemorrhage from retained placental products, for which the patient underwent uterine curettage. Vital signs are within normal limits. Speculum examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. The uterus is normal in size, and no adnexal masses are palpated. Midcycle serum studies show:


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
3.9 μU/mL


Follicle-stimulating hormone
54 mIU/mL


Luteinizing hormone
80 mIU/mL


Prolactin
15 ng/mL


β-hCG
negative


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's infertility?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anovulation can be caused by primary hypogonadism (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome, primary ovarian insufficiency) or secondary hypogonadism (e.g., hyperprolactinemia due to prolactinoma). In this patient with normal serum hormone studies, amenorrhea and infertility are unlikely to be caused by anovulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis can manifest with cyclic pelvic pain and infertility. However, this patient has amenorrhea, which is not a feature of endometriosis. In addition, physical examination in endometriosis typically shows rectovaginal tenderness, adnexal masses, and lateral displacement of the cervix, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Sheehan syndrome (SS) is caused by ischemia and necrosis of the pituitary gland due to severe postpartum hemorrhage. Patients with SS typically have LH and FSH deficiency. Although SS also manifests with secondary amenorrhea and infertility, this patient has normal levels of LH and FSH, making SS unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Overt hypothyroidism may result in amenorrhea and subsequent infertility. However, a compensatory increase in thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels is expected, whereas this patient's TSH is within the reference range.

E) CORRECT:

Intrauterine adhesions, also known as Asherman syndrome (AS), most commonly occur following intrauterine instrumentation (e.g., dilation and curettage) and may manifest with infertility, secondary amenorrhea, and cyclic pelvic pain (due to blood accumulation in the uterus). Serum concentrations of FSH, LH, and prolactin are typically within the reference ranges. Hysteroscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis. AS is usually asymptomatic; the standard treatment for symptomatic AS is hysteroscopic resection of the adhesions.

The workup of secondary amenorrhea includes a progestin and/or an estrogen/progestin withdrawal test, which induces withdrawal bleeding in patients with anovulatory cycles (e.g., due to polycystic ovary syndrome, primary ovarian insufficiency). Because of the presence of intrauterine adhesions and blocked outflow tract, these tests do not cause bleeding in patients with AS.
questions.hint: This patient's infertility and secondary amenorrhea most likely developed as a complication of uterine curettage.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with 5 months of absent menses to the clinic. She had a first-trimester miscarriage 6 months ago and underwent a suction curettage. There is no history of pelvic pain or systemic illness. A progestin challenge test does not yield withdrawal bleeding (see report).
Transvaginal ultrasound: Thin endometrial stripe with no focal abnormalities
Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Obstructive lesion at the uterus-cervix junction
Intrauterine adhesions from prior endometrial trauma

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Premature ovarian insufficiency (POI) results in reduced estrogen, causing a thin endometrial lining and lack of withdrawal bleeding. POI typically presents with menopausal symptoms and elevated gonadotropins, which are not noted here. The patient's recent suction curettage suggests intrauterine scarring, impairing endometrial regeneration despite adequate estrogen, rather than ovarian insufficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypothalamic dysfunction leads to low GnRH secretion, reducing FSH and LH release and estrogen production. This can cause a thin endometrial stripe and absence of withdrawal bleeding. However, it is usually associated with stress, weight loss, or excessive exercise, which are not present here. The patient's recent suction curettage is a known risk for intrauterine adhesions, explaining the findings better than hypothalamic dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

An obstructive lesion would cause blood retention, leading to hematometra and cyclic pelvic pain. The endometrial lining would be hormonally responsive, with withdrawal bleeding trapped behind the obstruction. The ultrasound shows a thin endometrial stripe without blood accumulation, and the patient lacks cyclic pain, indicating an endometrial issue rather than a physical blockage.

D) CORRECT:

Asherman syndrome results from trauma to the basal layer of the endometrium, often after procedures like suction curettage. This trauma leads to intrauterine adhesions, replacing normal endometrial tissue and inhibiting cyclic proliferation. The absence of withdrawal bleeding after a progestin challenge test indicates insufficient functional endometrium, while a thin endometrial stripe on ultrasound suggests atrophic endometrium due to scarring. These findings align with Asherman syndrome, a sequela of intrauterine adhesions following endometrial injury.

Key learning point: Asherman syndrome is characterized by intrauterine adhesions, often following surgical procedures like dilatation and curettage, leading to amenorrhea and lack of response to hormonal withdrawal tests.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old G2P2 woman presents to the clinic with nine months of amenorrhea following a dilation and curettage for retained products of conception. She reports minimal spotting instead of regular menses since the procedure. Physical examination shows no obvious external abnormalities (see report).
Transvaginal ultrasound: Normal-sized uterus with an irregular endometrial cavity
What is the most likely underlying cause of her current presentation?

choices.text: Destruction of the basalis layer resulting in intrauterine synechiae
Primary ovarian insufficiency causing low estrogen levels
Hypothalamic suppression leading to decreased gonadotropin-releasing hormone release

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pituitary infarction, as in Sheehan syndrome, follows significant postpartum hemorrhage and causes widespread hormone deficiencies, including low gonadotropins, leading to amenorrhea. This patient lacks a history of severe hemorrhage or systemic pituitary insufficiency signs. The irregular endometrial cavity on ultrasound suggests localized endometrial injury, not pituitary-related amenorrhea.

B) CORRECT:

The basalis layer of the endometrium is crucial for regenerating the functional layer lost during menstruation. In this patient, dilation and curettage likely caused trauma to the basalis layer, leading to intrauterine synechiae, or fibrous bands, which disrupt the endometrial architecture. This disruption results in diminished or absent menses, as evidenced by her amenorrhea and minimal spotting. The ultrasound finding of an irregular endometrial cavity supports the presence of fibrotic changes due to injury of the regenerative layer.

Key learning point: Damage to the basalis zone of the endometrium can lead to Asherman's syndrome, characterized by amenorrhea due to the inability to regenerate the endometrial lining.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency results in low estrogen and a uniformly thin endometrium. This patient's amenorrhea began after dilation and curettage, indicating a uterine cause. The irregular endometrial cavity on ultrasound and absence of hypoestrogenic symptoms, such as hot flashes, make ovarian insufficiency unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothalamic suppression, often due to stress, exercise, or weight loss, leads to low estrogen levels and a uniformly thin endometrium. This patient's history of dilation and curettage and the ultrasound finding of an irregular endometrial cavity suggest a localized intrauterine process, such as endometrial scarring, rather than hypothalamic suppression.

questions.text: You are seeing a 17-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic because she has not had a menstrual period. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. On examination, she has normal breast development. Pubic hair is coarse and extends to the inner thighs. Pelvic examination reveals a blind vaginal pouch. Ultrasonography shows the presence of ovaries but no uterus. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mullerian duct agenesis is a rare congenital defect in which the Mullerian ducts fail to fuse. As a result, the uterus, cervix, and upper third of the vagina are atretic. Patients are asymptomatic until puberty when they present with primary amenorrhea. The secondary sexual characteristics are usually normal since the gonads are functional and the patient has a normal female karyotype. The treatment is primarily surgical, involving uterine transplantation and vaginoplasty.

Key learning point: Müllerian duct agenesis causes primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics, absent uterus, and a blind vaginal pouch, while ovarian function and karyotype remain normal.
Image Description:

(1) Uniform (sex-independent) embryonic genital (and urinary) structures (before week 8)
(2) Degeneration of the Wolffian ducts and differentiation of the Mullerian ducts
(3) Fully developed female urogenital organs

B) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of 17-alpha hydroxylase results in a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia that may manifest with primary amenorrhea in females as a result of impaired estrogen synthesis. However, a uterus would be present on ultrasonography and external genitalia would be normal. Pubic hair would be scarce due to hypoandrogenism, and breast development would be delayed. Patients would also have other clinical features such as hypertension and hyperpigmentation.

C) INCORRECT:

5-alpha-reductase deficiency may present with primary amenorrhea, a blind vaginal loop, and an absent uterus on ultrasonography. However, patients would also have features of virilization (e.g., clitoromegaly, hirsutism, and deepening of the voice) at the time of puberty, and the ultrasound would reveal undescended testes.

D) INCORRECT:

Failure of recanalization of the Mullerian duct would result in a transverse vaginal septum, which would manifest with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and a blind vaginal pouch. However, patients would complain of periodic abdominal pain due to hematometra and would show a distended uterine cavity with variable internal echogenicity on ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome present with primary amenorrhea, a blind vaginal pouch, an absent uterus on ultrasonography, and normal breast development. However, patients would not have pubic hair, since the growth of pubic hair is dependent on androgens. Ultrasonography would reveal undescended testicles.
questions.hint: Urological malformations (e.g., renal agenesis, horseshoe kidney, pelvic kidney) are commonly associated with this condition.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain. She reports having had multiple similar episodes over the past 9 months, each lasting 4–5 days. She has not yet had menarche. On examination, there is suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Pubic hair and breast development are Tanner stage 4. Pelvic examination reveals bulging, bluish tissue 1 cm inside the vaginal introitus. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Müllerian agenesis (MA) manifests as primary amenorrhea in patients with normal secondary sexual characteristics. This condition causes vaginal agenesis; pelvic examination typically shows normal external genitalia and a vaginal dimple (small vaginal pouch) rather than a mass at the vaginal introitus. In almost all cases, individuals with MA also have uterine agenesis or underdevelopment and thus do not menstruate. Rarely, these individuals have a rudimentary uterus and can develop cyclic pelvic pain due to menstruation. However, because the menstrual blood cannot pass into the lower vagina, a mass would not be present at the vaginal introitus.

B) INCORRECT:

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) manifests with primary amenorrhea in patients with normal breast development and female external genitalia. However, in contrast to this patient, individuals with AIS have very sparse or absent pubic hair. Pelvic examination shows a blind-ending vaginal pouch rather than a mass at the vaginal introitus. Cryptorchid testes may be palpable as bilateral masses in the abdominal or inguinal region. AIS does not cause cyclical pelvic pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis causes cyclical pelvic pain, which is seen in this patient, but does not manifest with primary amenorrhea or a bulging, bluish mass within the vaginal introitus. Additionally, this condition typically manifests in women who are 25–35 years of age and is unlikely to develop in an adolescent patient.

D) CORRECT:

Imperforate hymen manifests with primary amenorrhea, cyclical pelvic pain, and otherwise normal secondary sexual characteristics. As is the case here, patients with an imperforate hymen are asymptomatic until menarche, when the obstructed outflow of menstrual blood distends the vaginal tract and uterus and results in a characteristic bulging, bluish mass at the vaginal introitus (hematocolpos). Treatment of imperforate hymen includes hymenectomy and consequent evacuation of the retained blood.

Key learning point: Imperforate hymen presents in adolescents with primary amenorrhea, cyclic pelvic pain, and a bulging, bluish vaginal mass due to retained menstrual blood (hematocolpos).

E) INCORRECT:

Labial adhesions manifest with a thin, vertical midline fold in the perineum due to adhesions between the labia minora. This condition does not cause a mass at the vaginal introitus and is typically asymptomatic. Additionally, this condition usually affects infants and young children (peak incidence of 2 years of age) and spontaneously resolves around the time of puberty, when increased circulating levels of estrogen thicken the labia. Patients with labial adhesions typically do not have primary amenorrhea.
questions.hint: Recurrent lower abdominal pain in a 15-year-old female with age-appropriate secondary sexual characteristics suggests that menstruation is in fact occurring but is hidden (cryptomenorrhea).
